Apr 6

I quit Instagram for seven weeks and here’s what happened

Every year before Easter I give up something I enjoy for seven weeks. If you’re familiar with Lent, you can mark it in different ways. Some people are really strict and go fully vegan and some just deprive themselves from alcohol. I like to practice self-restraint and normally resist meat, sweets and alcohol for 46 days. But this time I wanted to try out something new so I decided to completely abstain from Instagram.

Why quitting Instagram?

I must admit that going without Instagram for such a long time was the hardest challenge. But I was feeling overwhelmed and somehow distracted with my social media habits. I was waking up, grabbing my phone and checking my Insta feed. I realised that was mindlessly browsing photos of people I don’t even know or will ever meet. I was using social media to fill time, but also looking for affirmation. Some days I was constantly thinking about what I am going to post next even though I have a tiny private account. And after Instagram switched from chronological to order of showing photos to what it thinks I may be more interested in, the glossy and retouched content even gained on importance. Even the granulary targeted ads were disturbing me as companies can target users by their location, demographic, interests, actions or lookalike audiences. It was time to take a break.

Changing behaviour

On Shrove Tuesday I removed the app from my phone. Right after I was unsure what to do with myself. It felt unusual for a couple of days as I was missing the activities of my friends. As I recently moved to another city, Instagram was a great way to stay updated. But after a week I recognized that I can invest the sheer amount of time in more mindful activities than browsing photos. At least I had time to read magazines and even started to learn Swift (a programming language created by Apple). Besides that I started to use my news apps more often.

Substituting the feed

I felt that I didn’t really spend less time on my phone. I was rather substituting Insta with other apps. I even re-installed Snapchat. But since the majority of my friends switched to Instagram Stories, my Snapchat feed was almost empty. I also downloaded musical.ly and tried to record some songs bunch of times. I started to use YouTube, Twitter and Facebook more often though my friends stopped posting status updates years ago. By coincidence Facebook started the global release of Whatsapp and Facebook Stories which you can share with specific users. So I could not resist and shared some pictures via the new feature. I also didn’t go blind about what happens on my Insta account as Instagram tries to reactivate lapsed users. Every week I got an email informing me about my new followers, likes and comments. Only one click and I could get the app again.

Shifting priorities

I do miss Instagram. But the “detox” showed me that I care less about comparing myself to others’ lives. I could reclaim my precious time after noticing how much can of it be wasted browsing social networks without knowing. When I go to sleep now I don’t have to look at my accounts or answering all the comments. I simply avoid all the noise: pictures of babies, cat content and irrelevant #OOTDs. One recent study proves that there is a relationship between self-promotional social media behavior and narcissistic traits. And I definitely do not want to feed my ego applying tons of filters and adjusting saturation. Nevertheless I am looking forward to use Instagram again, mostly because of people with the same interests who sometimes inspire me.
